questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained a head injury following a motorcycle accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness at the scene. Upon regaining consciousness, he developed a severe headache and began to feel drowsy. A CT scan of the head is performed. Which of the following should be the management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Immediate surgical decompression:

  • The above CT scan shows Biconvex or lenticular or lens shaped hyperdense lesion which is characteristic of Extradural hemorrhage.
  • Patient complains of severe headache and drowsiness. Delaying treatment can lead to increase in ICP which can cause uncal herniation and 3rd nerve palsy.
  • This patient requires immediate surgical decompression by Burr hole or craniotomy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anticoagulants: Anticoagulants are not used in the treatment as it increases the risk of bleeding or exacerbate the current bleeding.

Option C - Observation in ICU: Observation in ICU is not recommended as the patient already exhibits lucid interval and delaying surgery can lead to increased ICP.

Option D - Mannitol administration: Mannitol administration is contraindicated in EDH as it increases the mass of the lesion due to water loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in the primary survey of trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NCCT head:

  • NCCT head is not an adjunct of primary survey in trauma cases.
  • NCCT head is only done after stabilizing the patient as part of tertiary survey, which includes comprehensive evaluation of the patient by physical examination, radiographic imaging.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CXR: Chest X-rays is an adjunct of primary survey and it is performed to rule out thoracic blood loss (to rule out hemothorax, pneumothorax, and perforation peritonitis).

Option C - Intubation: Endotracheal intubation is performed in case of limited respiratory efforts or dyspnea or low GCS.

Option D - ICD drainage: ICD drainage is performed in cases of massive hemothorax, tension pneumothorax and it is an adjunct of primary survey.

questions.text: Mount fuji sign on CT is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumocephalus:

  • Mount Fuji sign is seen in tension pneumocephalus.
  • The black area in the T represents air, that is collection of air in the frontal region.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum on CT shows gas anteriorly and gas in the bowel loops.

Option C - Pneumomediastinum: Pneumomediastinum could show ring around artery sign, continuous diaphragm sign, extrapleural sign, and Naclerio V sign.

Option D - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax shows gas around the edges of the lung.

questions.text: During a complicated delivery, a mother died. Which of the following is the most common Direct cause of maternal death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hemorrhage

  • Hemorrhage, is the most common Direct cause of maternal death during complicated delivery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Embolism: An embolism refers to the sudden blockage of a blood vessel by a clot (embolus), which can potentially lead to serious complications. Pulmonary embolism, where a blood clot travels to the lungs, is a known cause of maternal mortality. It can occur during pregnancy, childbirth, or the postpartum period. An embolism can obstruct blood flow and lead to respiratory distress, shock, and even death. While embolism can be a cause of maternal death, but is not the most common direct cause.

Option B - Heart Disease: Pre-existing heart disease in a pregnant woman can increase the risk of complications during childbirth. Cardiac events, such as heart failure, myocardial infarction (heart attack), or arrhythmias, can contribute to maternal death. However, but is not the most common direct cause.

Option D - Anemia: Anemia is most common indirect cause of death.

questions.text: Which fluid is administered most commonly during intraoperative blood loss?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Crystalloids: 

  • Crystalloids are the most commonly administered fluid for intraoperative fluid administration, especially in minor surgical procedures.
  • Crystalloids are cost-effective, readily available, and generally safe.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presented in the OPD with bloody discharge from the nipple. On examination, it was found to be from a single lactiferous duct. What is the treatment for bloody nipple discharge with single duct involvement?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Microdochectomy 

  • Microdochectomy involves the surgical removal of the affected lactiferous duct.
  • It is the treatment of choice for cases of bloody nipple discharge originating from a single duct.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Hadfield’s procedure:

  • Hadfield's procedure is an obsolete surgical procedure used in the past for the treatment of mammary duct ectasia.
  • It is not used for bloody nipple discharge from a single duct.

Option C - Microdiscectomy: Microdiscectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat herniated spinal discs that are pressing on nerves.

Option D - IV antibiotics + Incision: It is considered in cases of infection-related symptoms or abscesses in the breast and is not the primary treatment for bloody nipple discharge with single duct involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct for the device depicted below:

choices.text: Based on infrared emitted from RBCs
Checks thickness of artery and vein

questions.solution:
Correct option A - Based on infrared emitted from RBCs:

  • The device depicted is a Doppler ultrasound machine, which uses sound waves and not infrared emitted from RBCs, to create images of blood flow.
  • Doppler ultrasound works by measuring the frequency shift of sound waves reflected off moving red blood cells.
  • This shift in frequency, known as the Doppler effect, helps in visualizing blood flow direction and velocity.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Localizes calcified plaque:

  • Doppler ultrasound can identify areas of calcified plaque within blood vessels.
  • However, it might not provide as detailed information about the plaque compared to other imaging techniques like CT scans or angiography.

Option C - Checks blood flow : Doppler ultrasound is primarily used for assessing blood flow and vascular conditions. 

Option D - Checks thickness of artery and vein:

  • Doppler ultrasound can be used to measure the thickness of arteries and veins, as well as assess their overall structure and condition.
  • It is particularly useful for evaluating conditions like atherosclerosis, where arteries might become thicker due to plaque buildup.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication usually associated with the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumothorax

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown in the image is central line placement. A potential complication of this procedure is pneumothorax, which occurs when air enters the pleural space, leading to the partial or complete collapse of the lung. This can happen when the central line needle or catheter is inserted into the subclavian or jugular veins.

The central venous catheter is used for fluid, medication, and nutrition administration.

  • The tip is located in the superior vena cava.
  • Order of preference: Subclavian vein > Internal jugular vein > Femoral vein
  • Inside OT: Internal jugular vein
  • Outside OT: Subclavian vein.
  • Complications: Catheter-related sepsis, pneumothorax.

 

Incorrect Options:

Aspiration (Option A) involves inhaling stomach contents or foreign material into the lungs. Although it can occur in various clinical situations, it is not typically associated with central line placement.

Torticollis (Option B), or wry neck, is a condition where the neck muscles involuntarily contract, causing the neck to twist to one side. This is not a complication directly related to central line placement.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis (Option D) is a complication typically associated with surgeries or procedures involving the neck or chest, such as thyroid or thoracic surgery. It is not commonly linked to central line placement.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which one is NOT acknowledged as a potential complication resulting from a significant blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypernatremia

Explanation:

  • Hypernatremia is not typically a complication of blood transfusion.

Complications of massive blood transfusion:

  • Hypocalcemia: (Option A)
    • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and other blood products are preserved with citrate, an anticoagulant.
    • Citrate binds to ionised calcium (Ca²⁺) in the recipient's blood, reducing the free calcium level - hypocalcemia.
    • Presents as muscle spasms, cardiac arrhythmias, and decreased myocardial contractility.
  • Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Citrate is metabolised in the liver to bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻).
    • Rapid transfusion of citrate-containing blood products can overwhelm the liver’s ability to metabolise citrate, leading to an increase in bicarbonate levels.
    • This results in metabolic alkalosis
  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Stored blood undergoes hemolysis over time, releasing potassium from red blood cells into the plasma.
    • Transfusion of large volumes of stored blood can introduce a significant potassium load, causing hyperkalemia.
    • Presents with cardiac arrhythmias, especially in patients with pre-existing kidney dysfunction.
  • Hypothermia: (Option C)
    • Rapid transfusion of cold-stored blood products (typically kept at 1–6°C) can lower the patient’s core body temperature.
  • Coagulopathy:
    • Massive transfusion dilutes clotting factors and platelets, leading to dilutional coagulopathy.
    • Hypothermia and hypocalcemia exacerbate this by impairing the function of coagulation enzymes and platelets.
  • Hypokalemia: (Option B)
    • Post-transfusion, potassium that had leaked out of stored red blood cells can re-enter the cells in vivo.
    • This shift can lead to hypokalemia, especially if the patient has a strong cellular uptake of potassium.

questions.text: What is the minimum platelet count necessary for most surgical procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 50,000 (10^9/L)

Explanation:

  • A platelet count of at least 50,000 (10^9/L) is generally considered the minimum for performing most surgical procedures safely, as it helps minimise the risk of bleeding.

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines (2015):

  • For invasive procedures or surgery: Platelet counts should be increased above 50,000/μL.
  • For patients at high risk of bleeding: A platelet count of 50,000-75,000/μL is considered appropriate.
  • For surgery at critical sites: A platelet count of > 100,000/μL is recommended.

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

Explanation:

The image likely depicts a procedure for establishing an intraosseous route to administer IV fluids. This technique is commonly used when IV access is difficult or not possible. Intraosseous infusion (IO) involves injecting drugs, fluids, or blood products directly into the medullary cavity of the bone, providing a non-collapsible entry point into the systemic venous system.

  • IO route is an alternative to the IV route in the transfusion of fluids in shock.
  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into the central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately to central circulation. So, bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

 

Intraosseous cannulation:

  • Intraosseous cannulation is a widely accepted technique for both children and adults.
  • The EZ-IO® system is commonly used in the UK.
  • A hand-held electric drill is used to insert a cannula through the tibia or humeral head into the marrow cavity.
  • The response time for drug administration is similar to intravenous (IV) access.
  • Entire resuscitations, including anaesthetic drugs and fluids, can be performed through intraosseous cannulae.
  • Due to resistance to flow, fluids should be given as boluses using a 50 mL syringe.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with a lesion as shown in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago, and the scar has grown beyond the boundary of the initial injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Keloid

Explanation:

  • The lesion described is most consistent with a keloid that is characterised by the excessive growth of scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original injury, and it often develops after trauma or surgery. They are known for being raised, thick, and sometimes itchy.

 

Hypertrophic scar: (Option B)

  • Confined to the original wound boundaries, unlike keloids that extend beyond the wound area.
  • Raised scar with excess collagen.
  • It grows rapidly and contains myofibroblasts.
  • It tends to regress over time (months) and recur less compared to keloid

 

Keloid:

  • Scar grows beyond the original wound boundaries and doesn’t regress.
  • More common among African Americans.
  • Develops after deep dermal injuries.

 

Hemangiomas (Option A) are benign tumours of blood vessels, usually present at birth or appearing in early childhood. They do not develop as a result of trauma.

Hypertrophic scar: Similar to a keloid, a hypertrophic scar is the result of an overactive healing process. However, unlike keloids, hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound boundaries.

Neurofibromas (Option D) are benign nerve sheath tumours, commonly associated with genetic conditions like neurofibromatosis rather than trauma.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a 5-day fever history and signs of hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil proportion, and serum creatinine. The intern doctor plans to assess the quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score for prognosis prediction and hospitalisation duration. Which elements are part of the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) SBP, RR, and GCS score

Explanation:

  • The qSOFA score includes three components: Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) less than 100 mmHg, Respiratory Rate (RR) greater than or equal to 22 breaths per minute, and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. These components help in the assessment of organ failure and sepsis prognosis.

Sepsis & q SOFA:

Sepsis is now defined as an increase of 2 or more points in the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score from baseline. However, calculating the full SOFA score can be complex and requires lab results, so a simpler tool, the quick SOFA (qSOFA) score, was introduced for bedside use.

  • qSOFA Criteria: qSOFA involves evaluating three key signs:
    • Respiratory rate ≥ 22 breaths per minute
    • Altered mental status (GCS score)
    • Systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mmHg (hypotension)
  • If a patient meets at least 2 of the 3 qSOFA criteria and is at risk for sepsis (e.g., has an infection), further evaluation should be conducted to identify the source of infection and initiate appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Which class of hypovolemic shock, according to Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines, is characterised by the absence of urine output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Class IV

Explanation:

  • According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS), in the classes of hypovolemic shock, class IV is characterised by the absence of urine output.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after sustaining an RTA and injury to the lower chest. On presentation, the patient is stable, and vitals are normal. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct ANswer: A) eFAST

Explanation:

In the scenario of an RTA with a stable patient, normal vitals, and clear lung fields, the most appropriate next step would be an extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (eFAST).

  • It is a rapid bedside ultrasound to detect life-threatening injuries in trauma patients, focusing on the chest and abdomen.
  • It assesses the pericardium, pleural spaces, and abdominal cavity for air or fluid.
  • If clear lung fields rule out pneumothorax or hemothorax, eFAST helps detect other bleeding sources, like intraperitoneal bleeding.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST)

  • Purpose: Assess for free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavities, and pericardium. (Option A)
  • Nature of Injury: Not used to determine the specific nature or extent of injury.
  • Advantages: (Option A)
    • Rapid, reproducible, portable, and non-invasive bedside test.
    • Can be performed simultaneously with resuscitation.
    • Accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood.
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent and may be unreliable in obese patients or when the bowel is full of gas.
    • Low sensitivity (29–35%) for detecting hollow viscus or solid organ injuries without haemoperitoneum.
    • Unreliable for excluding injuries in penetrating trauma.
    • Requires repeat or supplementary investigations if needed.
    • Unreliable for assessing retroperitoneum.

 

Tube thoracostomy (Option B) is used for pneumothorax or hemothorax, but since the chest radiography shows clear lung fields, it’s not needed at this point.

CECT chest (Option C) and abdomen (Option D) are more invasive imaging options. Since the chest radiography is clear and the patient is stable, eFAST is a quicker, non-invasive first step to assess for other injuries, such as abdominal or retroperitoneal bleeding, before considering further imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the qSOFA score components?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lactate dehydrogenase

Explanation:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is not part of the components used in the qSOFA (quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) Score.

  • It is a simplified, rapid assessment scale developed as an easier alternative to the more complex SOFA score, which requires laboratory tests.
  • The Third International Consensus Definition of Sepsis recommends using qSOFA to identify patients with sepsis (higher risk of death, prolonged ICU stay, and increased need for ICU admission).
  • Components:
    • Respiratory rate ≥22 (Option A ruled out)
    • Altered mental status (Option C ruled out)
    • Systolic blood pressure ≤100 mm Hg. (Option D ruled out)
  • Interpretation: qSOFA ≥2 (with a concern for infection) is associated with a significantly greater risk of death or prolonged ICU stay.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which pairing correctly matches the trauma patients brought to the casualty?

choices.text: Penetrating injury to eustachian tube - CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye - Battle sign

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gaze palsy - Mid brain lesion

Explanation:

  • Gaze palsy, a difficulty in eye movement, can result from damage to structures in the midbrain, such as the third cranial nerve nucleus and paramedian pontine reticular formation.

 

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) - Pin point pupil (Option A): EDH causes a dilated, non-reactive pupil due to pressure on the oculomotor nerve (CN III), while pinpoint pupils are more associated with opioid overdose or pontine lesions.

Penetrating injury to eustachian tube - CSF otorrhea (Option B): Penetrating injury to the eustachian tube may cause complications but not CSF otorrhea, which is typically linked to basilar skull fractures and injury to the temporal bone.

Penetrating injury to eye - Battle sign (Option C): Battle sign, bruising behind the ear, is associated with basilar skull fractures, not penetrating eye injuries, which present with hyphema, corneal damage, or visual disturbances.

questions.text: In all types of shock, which of the following is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduced tissue perfusion

Explanation:

  • Reduced tissue perfusion, a hallmark of all Shock types, results in inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery, leading to organ dysfunction.
    • It is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. (Option A)

Classification

Type of Shock

Mechanism

Examples

Hypovolemic Shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

Hemorrhage, Dehydration

Cardiogenic Shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

Myocardial Infarction, Cardiac Dysrhythmias

Obstructive Shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling

Cardiac Tamponade, Tension Pneumothorax

Distributive Shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

Septic Shock, Anaphylactic Shock

Endocrine Shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic, or distributive shock mechanisms

Addisonian Crisis, Myxedema Coma

 

Increased peripheral resistance (Option B) may occur in some shock types (e.g., hypovolemic, cardiogenic) as compensation to maintain blood pressure, but it's not universal. In septic shock, peripheral resistance is often decreased due to vasodilation.

Decreased respiratory rate (Option C) may occur in certain shock types (e.g., neurogenic, severe hypovolemic), but increased respiratory rate (tachypnea) is more common as the body compensates for low oxygen levels, making it not universal in all shock types.

Cold clammy skin (Option D) occurs in some shock types (e.g., hypovolemic, cardiogenic) due to vasoconstriction, but not in all. In septic shock, skin may be warm and flushed due to vasodilation.

questions.text: For the purpose of preventing surgical site infection, what is the recommended technique and optimal timing for hair removal prior to surgery?

choices.text: On the OT table with electric hair clippers
With a razor 24 hours before surgery
With a hair removal cream on the previous day
On the OT table with a razor

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: On the OT table with electric hair clippers

  • The ideal time and method of removing hair before surgery to avoid surgical site infection are on the OT table with electric hair clippers. This method is preferred over the other options because it is considered to be the safest and most effective method for hair removal. 
  • Electric clippers are less likely to cause nicks, cuts, or skin irritation than a razor or hair removal cream. Moreover, electric clippers are designed to cut the hair close to the skin without causing any damage to the skin itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Removing hair with a razor 24 hours before surgery is not recommended because it can cause microscopic cuts on the skin, increasing the risk of infection. 

Option C: Hair removal creams can cause skin irritation, which can also increase the risk of infection.

Option D: Removing hair on the OT table with a razor is not a recommended method because it increases the risk of infection due to the fact that it is more difficult to maintain a sterile environment in the operating room when using a razor.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department after being involved in a car accident. The patient is experiencing difficulty breathing and their neck veins appear dilated. The x-ray reveals a significant amount of air on the left side. What is the most appropriate course of action for treatment?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space

questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

  • This scenario's next best management step is the wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space. This is indicative of a tension pneumothorax, which is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment.
  • A tension pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space (between the lungs and the chest wall) and becomes trapped. As more air accumulates, it can cause a shift in the position of the mediastinum (the area in the chest between the lungs that contains the heart, great vessels, and other structures), leading to compression of the lungs and blood vessels. This can result in respiratory distress, hypoxemia (low oxygen levels in the blood), and cardiovascular collapse.
  • Treating of a tension pneumothorax involves relieving the pressure in the pleural space by inserting a needle or catheter into the chest cavity to allow the trapped air to escape. The insertion site is typically in the 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line (i.e., the space between the fifth and sixth ribs, in line with the middle of the collarbone). This procedure is known as needle decompression or thoracostomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Endotracheal intubation involves placing a tube through the mouth or nose into the trachea to provide mechanical ventilation and oxygenation. While this may be necessary in some cases of respiratory distress, it does not address the underlying problem of a tension pneumothorax.

Option C: Tracheostomy is a surgical procedure that involves creating a small opening in the neck and inserting a tube directly into the trachea. This is typically done in upper airway obstruction or long-term mechanical ventilation cases. Again, this does not address the underlying problem of a tension pneumothorax.

Option D: Pericardiocentesis involves inserting a needle into the pericardial sac (the membrane surrounding the heart) to drain fluid or blood that may be compressing the heart. While this can be a life-saving procedure in cases of cardiac tamponade (heart compression due to fluid or blood in the pericardial sac), it is not indicated in a tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A patient sustained a crush injury on their right arm. He was taken to the hospital and on examination, his arm was pulseless, swollen, and dark red. What would be the best way to manage this case?
questions.solution:
• The best way to manage a patient with a crush injury to the arm that presents with a pulseless, swollen, and dark red arm is fasciotomy.
  • A crush injury can result in a significant amount of tissue damage, which can lead to the development of compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome occurs when there is increased pressure within a muscle compartment, which can result in tissue damage, nerve injury, and even loss of limb function. In this case, the patient's pulseless, swollen, and dark red arm is likely indicative of compartment syndrome, which is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent irreversible tissue damage.
  • Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure that involves making an incision into the affected compartment to relieve pressure and improve blood flow to the affected tissues. It is the recommended treatment for compartment syndrome in cases where conservative measures, such as elevation and pain management, are ineffective.

Incorrect Choices: 

  • Option a: Intraosseous administration of fluids is a method of delivering fluids and medications directly into the bone marrow, bypassing the need for venous access. While this may be useful in certain situations, such as when venous access is difficult to obtain, it is not the appropriate treatment for compartment syndrome.
  • Option b: Acidification of urine may be used in the management of certain types of poisoning, such as aspirin overdose, but it is not indicated in the treatment of a crush injury.
  • Option d: Hemodialysis is a treatment for kidney failure and is not indicated in the treatment of a crush injury.

questions.text: Which of these is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified by assessing the breathing component of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

  • Tension Pneumothorax is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified by assessing the patient's breathing component.
  • It occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space, increasing pressure on the lungs and heart, leading to lung collapse and impaired blood flow.
  • It can rapidly cause cardiovascular collapse and is fatal without prompt decompression.

 

Life-threatening Injuries

  • These can be remembered as the ‘deadly dozen’.
    • Six Immediately life-threatening injuries were managed during the primary survey.
    • Six Potentially life-threatening injuries were detected during the secondary survey.

 

Immediately life-threatening injuries

Potentially life-threatening injuries
  • Airway obstruction
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Massive haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Aortic injuries
  • Tracheobronchial injuries
  • Myocardial contusion
  • Rupture of the diaphragm
  • Oesophageal injuries
  • Pulmonary contusion

Cervical spine injury (Option A) can cause neurological complications, but it doesn’t directly compromise breathing, making it less life-threatening compared to other injuries in this context.

Blunt cardiac injury (Option C) primarily affects the heart, potentially leading to arrhythmias or cardiac rupture. While it can be life-threatening, it does not directly compromise breathing, unlike other injuries.

Laryngotracheal injury (Option D) can cause airway obstruction and breathing difficulties, but tension pneumothorax is more immediately life-threatening, rapidly leading to respiratory and cardiovascular collapse if untreated.

questions.text: Hand rub can be utilised in accordance with the standard hand hygiene protocol in all locations listed below, with the exception of:

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Explanation:

As per the WHO Standard Hand Hygiene Protocol, hand rub is not suitable for visibly soiled hands, and handwashing with soap and water is required to remove dirt and contaminants.

 

Indications:

  • Wash hands with soap and water when visibly dirty or visibly soiled with blood or other body fluids or after using the toilet. (Option A)
  • If exposure to potential spore-forming pathogens is strongly suspected or proven, including outbreaks of Clostridium difficile, hand washing with soap and water is the preferred means.
  • Use an alcohol-based hand rub as the preferred means for routine hand antisepsis in clinical situations if hands are not visibly soiled. (Option A)
    • If alcohol-based hand rub is not obtainable, wash hands with soap and water.
  • Perform hand hygiene:
    • Before and after touching the patient. (Option D ruled out)
    • Before handling an invasive device for patient care, regardless of whether or not gloves are used
    • After contact with body fluids or excretions, mucous membranes, non-intact skin, or wound dressings
    • If moving from a contaminated body site to another body site during the care of the same patient (Option B ruled out)
    • After contact with inanimate surfaces and objects (including medical equipment) in the immediate vicinity of the patient.
    • After removing sterile or non-sterile gloves. (Option C ruled out)
  • Before handling medication or preparing food, perform hand hygiene using an alcohol-based hand rub or wash hands with either plain or antimicrobial soap and water.
  • Soap and alcohol-based hand rubs should not be used concomitantly.

 

Technique:

  • Apply a palmful of alcohol-based hand rub and cover all surfaces of the hands. Rub hands until dry.
  • When washing hands with soap and water,
    • Wet hands with water and apply the amount of product necessary to cover all surfaces.
    • Rinse hands with water and dry thoroughly with a single-use towel.
    • Use clean, running water whenever possible.
    • Avoid using hot water, as repeated exposure to hot water may increase the risk of dermatitis.
    • Use towel to turn off the tap/faucet.
    • Dry hands thoroughly using a method that does not recontaminate hands.
    • Make sure towels are not used multiple times or by multiple people.
  • Liquid, bar, leaf or powdered forms of soap are acceptable.
    • When bar soap is used, small bars of soap in racks that facilitate drainage should be used to allow the bars to dry.

questions.text:
In the case of a patient arriving at the emergency department with a road traffic accident (RTA), what is the appropriate order of steps in their management?


	Cervial spine stabilisation
	Intubation
	IV cannulation
	CECT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

The proper sequence of Trauma Care management for a patient presenting with an RTA (road traffic accident) is 1, 2, 3, 4.

 

Primary Survey

It aims to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first and follows cABCDE.

  • c: Exsanguinating external haemorrhage
    • The exsanguinating external haemorrhage from massive arterial bleeding needs to be controlled even before the airway is managed.
  • A: Airway with cervical spine control
    • Cervical spine stabilisation. (Statement 1)
    • Assessment of the patient’s airway.
    • Compromised airway requires a stepwise progression:
      • Clearing the airway by suctioning secretions or blood.
      • Simple airway manoeuvres (jaw thrust, chin lift and insertion of an oropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal airway).
      • Advanced airway manoeuvres (intubation). (Statement 2)
  • B: Breathing and ventilation
    • High-flow oxygen.
    • Assess bilateral chest raise.
    • Assess breath sounds
    • Use pulse oximetry
    • Life-threatening chest pathology (tension pneumothorax, massive haemothorax and fail segment) should be diagnosed and managed.
  • C: Circulation and haemorrhage control
    • Monitor vitals.
    • Heart sounds
    • ECG
    • Intravenous (IV) access with at least two large-bore IV cannulae (central, peripheral). (Statement 3)
    • Blood was taken for cross-match and laboratory assessment.
    • Treatment of shock.
    • Control of external bleeding.
  • D: Disability
    • Neurological examination.
    • Use required tubes like catheters, Ryle’s tube.
  • E: Exposure
    • Undress the patient
    • Hypothermia assessment.
    • Assess injuries (imaging like USG, CT scan, MRI). (Statement 4)
    • Examine joints, bones, abdomen, and other systems.
    • Look for identification marks.

 

Secondary Survey:

  • Detailed top-to-toe examinations after life-threatening injuries have been identified and managed during the primary survey.
  • Patients may be intubated and unresponsive at this point, limiting the accuracy of clinical examination.

 

Tertiary survey

  • After extubation, identify any missed ‘minor’ injuries (scaphoid fracture in the wrist or a rotator cuff tear in the shoulder).
  • These injuries have the potential to cause significant long-term disability.

questions.text: What does the number (14Fr) marked on the Foley catheter correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Outer tube diameter

 

Explanation:

The number (14Fr) marked on the Foley’s Catheter indicates its outer tube diameter, measured in French (Fr) units, where 1 French equals 0.33 mm.

Material

LATEX - Less irritation & crust formation

Silicone Coating- for Prolonged use (up to 3 months)

Types
  • 2-way Foley catheter
  • 3-way Foley catheter

Channels

2-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: For drainage of urine
  • Small channel: For inflating balloon

3-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: for drainage of urine
  • Additional channel for irrigation

Balloon Inflation
  • 20-30 ml saline for self-retaining
  • 30-50 ml of saline for a hemostatic compression effect

Sizes (French scale)

Pediatric patients: 4, 6, 8, 10

Adult patients: 12, 14, 16, 18

Size Calculation

Outer diameter of catheter in mm = Fr/3 (Fr - French units)

E.g., if the size of the catheter is 18 French, then diameter = 18/3 = 6mm

Uses
  • To relieve urinary retention
  • To measure urine output
  • For administration of intravesical chemotherapy
  • 3 ways catheter - for Irrigation after TURP
  • May be used for supra-pubic cystostomy

Inner lumen diameter (Option A): The marked number refers to the outer diameter, not the inner lumen diameter, which impacts flow rate but is not indicated by the French size.

Length of the tube (Option B): The French size does not represent the catheter's length, which is usually marked separately and unrelated to the outer diameter measurement.

Bulb size (Option D): The French size does not indicate the balloon or bulb size, which is specified separately and unrelated to the outer tube diameter.

questions.text: Which of the following options does not represent one of the boundaries of the triangle of safety for the insertion of an ICD in a patient with a chest x-ray showing pneumothorax?

choices.text: Lateral edge of the pectoralis major

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mid-clavicular line

 

Explanation:

The mid-clavicular line is a vertical line through the clavicle and does not define the boundaries of the Triangle of Safety.

  • It is an anatomical region in the axilla that guides the safe position for intercostal catheter (ICC) placement.
    • With the arm abducted, the apex is the axilla, and the triangle is formed by the following:
      • The lateral border of the pectoralis major - anteriorly. (Option A ruled out)
      • The lateral border of the latissimus dorsi - posteriorly. (Option D ruled out)
      • Inferiorly, by a horizontal line from the nipple (commonly the 5th intercostal space). (Option B ruled out)

 

Triangle of safety

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is accurate concerning split-thickness and full-thickness skin grafts?


	Primary contractures are more in split skin grafts
	Secondary contractures are more in split skin grafts
	Primary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts
	Secondary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

  • Primary contraction is the initial recoil of the skin graft, which is more pronounced in full-thickness grafts.
  • Secondary contraction occurs after the healing process and is commonly seen in split-thickness grafts.

 

Feature

Split-Thickness Skin Graft

Full-Thickness Skin Graft

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction (Option A)

Secondary contracture is more significant

Primary contracture is more significant

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding central venous access and peripheral venous access?


	Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access.
	Isotonic saline and heparin are flushed to retain patency
	If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb.
	Vasopressors for septic shock are given in the central line to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

All four statements regarding central venous access and peripheral venous access are true.

  • Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access
    • It refers to inflammation of the vein
    • It is a common complication of peripheral venous access.
    • It can occur due to various factors, such as chemical irritation, mechanical irritation, or infection.
  • Isotonic saline and heparin are flushed to retain patency:
    • To maintain the patency of central venous access devices (such as central venous catheters or central lines), periodic flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is commonly performed.
    • This helps prevent clot formation and maintain the functionality of the line.
  • If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb.
    • An arteriovenous fistula (AVF) is a surgically created connection between an artery and a vein, typically used for hemodialysis.
    • When an AVF is present in a limb, it is generally recommended to avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb to prevent damage to the AVF and maintain its functionality.
  • Vasopressors for septic shock are given in the central line to avoid limb ischemia.
    • Vasopressors for septic shock can be administered through either central venous access or peripheral venous access, depending on the clinical situation and availability of access.
    • The choice of access depends on factors such as the stability of peripheral veins, the need for continuous infusion, and the urgency of treatment.
    • Limb ischemia is a potential complication of vasopressor administration, but it is not exclusive to peripheral venous access.

questions.text: Which one of the options listed below does not belong to the category of damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Vascular anastomosis is not typically performed during Damage Control Surgery, as the focus is on resuscitation, hemorrhage control, and stabilisation, with definitive repairs done later when the patient is stable.

 

Phases of Damage Control Surgery

Phase

Intervention

Steps

1

Recognition and Decision-making

Intubation, early rewarming, and prompt movement to operation theatre

2

Immediate Laparotomy

Control of bleeding, abdominal packing, and temporary abdominal closure

3

Intensive Care Unit

Ongoing resuscitation and normalisation of physiological and biochemical parameters

4

Re-Exploration

Definitive repair of all injuries

 

Stages of Damage Control Surgery

Stage

Intervention

1

Patient Selection

2

Control of haemorrhage and contamination (Option A, C ruled out)

3

Resuscitation in ICU (Option B ruled out)

4

Definitive Surgery

5

Abdomen closure

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding shock?

choices.text: Stage of compensatory shock is also called stage 2 of shock
Anaphylactic shock—is due to a Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
• Hypovolaemic Shock is the most common type of shock.
  • It is due to a reduced circulating volume.
  • Cause:
    • Haemorrhagic
      • Injury to the liver, spleen, and bone fractures
      • Haemothorax
      • Vascular injury
      • Severe bleeding on the table during surgeries
    • Nonhaemorrhagic
      • Poor fluid intake (dehydration)
      • Excessive fluid loss due to vomiting, diarrhoea, urinary loss (e.g. diabetes)
      • Evaporation or ‘third­spacing’, where fluid is lost into the gastrointestinal tract and interstitial spaces (bowel obstruction or pancreatitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Cold and clammy skin - due to inadequate tissue perfusion.
    • Reduced renal blood flow and GFR lead to oliguria, which may lead to anuria.
    • Cerebral blood flow is reduced, leading to drowsiness and confusion.
    • Tachypnoea - due to lactic acidosis
    • Tachycardia
    • Weak thready pulse
    • Sweating
  • Classification:

Parameter

Class I (Compensated Shock)

Class II (Hypoxemia)

Class III

Class IV (Refractory Shock)

Blood Loss

Up to 15%

15-30%

30-40%

More than 40%

Mechanism

Compensatory mechanisms maintain cardiac output.

Generalised vasoconstriction.

Decompensated shock.

Refractory shock.

Heart Rate

<100/min

100-120/min

120-140/min

>140/min

Blood Pressure

Normal

Hypotension

Marked hypotension

Profound hypotension

Respiratory Rate

Normal

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Tachypnea

Urine Output

>30 ml/hour

20-30 ml/hour

5-15 ml/hour

No urine output

Mental Status

Alert, normal

Anxious, mildly agitated

Confused, altered mental status

Comatose, lethargic

Anaerobic respiration produces carbon dioxide (Option A): Anaerobic respiration occurs in the absence of oxygen and results in the production of lactic acid, not carbon dioxide.

Stage of compensatory shock is also called stage 2 of shock (Option C): Class I refers to hypovolemic shock with up to 15% blood loss, where compensatory mechanisms sustain cardiac output, also known as Compensated Hypovolemic Shock.

Anaphylactic shock is due to Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction (Option D): Anaphylactic shocks due to Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The signs of reduced chest movement, tracheal deviation, and distended neck veins suggest a Tension Pneumothorax, which requires immediate decompression with needle thoracocentesis to relieve pressure and stabilise the patient before further interventions.

 

Tension Pneumothorax

It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology
  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology
  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation) and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management
  • Needle Thoracocentesis: Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line, or the "safe triangle".
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

Resuscitative thoracotomy (Option A) is used in traumatic cardiac arrest or severe haemorrhage, not for tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is urgent but not immediately fatal and should be treated with needle thoracocentesis.

ICD placement (Option B) is not the immediate treatment for tension pneumothorax, as it doesn't quickly relieve pressure. Needle thoracocentesis should be performed first, with ICD placement done afterwards for ongoing drainage.

Finger thoracotomy (Option D) is used for cardiac tamponade, not tension pneumothorax. Needle thoracocentesis is the preferred initial intervention for rapid decompression, while finger thoracotomy is reserved for later stages if needed.

questions.text: What steps should be taken to manage the case of a 24-year-old male who was hit by a motorbike while crossing the road, leading to abdominal injuries and bruising, with a blood pressure of 88/60 and IV fluids already administered, along with a positive FAST examination?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Exploratory laparotomy

Explanation:

  • Exploratory laparotomy indicated in patients with a positive FAST assessment to avoid further bleeding in the abdomen.
  • Hemodynamically unstable patients (BP <90 mmHg, signs of shock) with positive FAST should undergo emergency exploratory laparotomy to identify and control the source of bleeding.

CT scan (Abdominal/Pelvic) (Option A) is indicated only for hemodynamically stable patients. Since this patient is unstable, CT is not appropriate.

Abdominal MRI scan (Option B) MRIs are usually preferred for investigation of Soft tissue pathology, bone pathology, and head trauma.

Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage (DPL) (Option D) is rarely used now, as FAST is the preferred modality for detecting intra-abdominal bleeding.

questions.text: In a patient with liver cirrhosis, what is the primary cause of mortality when esophageal varices are present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Hypovolemic shock

Explanation:

  • Hypovolemic shock is circulatory failure due to loss of intravascular volume by variceal bleed.
  • This loss of intravascular volume loss will lead to tissue hypoperfusion and tissue hypoxia.
  • In cirrhosis, the blood flow to the liver is cut down, leading to more flow of blood through the veins of the oesophagus, leading to haemorrhage.

Cardiogenic shock (Option B) is characterised by the impaired ability of the heart to pump blood. (especially by the left ventricle)

Obstructive shock (Option C) is a condition wherein blood and oxygen fail to reach the organs. Examples include blood clots, collapsed lungs, tension pneumothorax, and pericardial Tamponade.

Distributive shock (Option D) This leads to poor tissue perfusion due to excessive vasodilation and poor distribution of blood flow to the heart, brain, and kidneys.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His heart rate was 100/min, respiratory rate was 24/min, and his chest X ray is given below. Which of the following is contraindicated in him?
questions.solution:
Xray findings:

  • Parts of bowel loops, including splenic flexure of the colon, are herniated into the thorax through a defect in the lateral aspect of the left hemidiaphragm, causing mild left lung base collapse.
  • The anterior arch of the left 5th and 6th ribs shows evidence of prior fracture.
  • A small metallic foreign body is also noted posterior to the cardiac shadow.
  • There are mild peribronchial opacities in the central segments of both lungs.

 

Chest tube insertion is generally contraindicated in patients with isolated rib fractures without associated pneumothorax or hemothorax .

Chest tube insertion is primarily performed to drain air or fluid from the pleural space when there is a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

 

Nasogastric tube insertion (Option A) is not directly contraindicated in a patient with diaphragmatic hernia. Nasogastric tube insertion is a common procedure performed in emergency departments to decompress the stomach and remove gastric contents.

 

Log roll (Option C) trauma precautions are generally recommended in trauma patients to minimise movement of the spine and reduce the risk of spinal cord injury.


Epidural anaesthesia (Option D) is a regional anesthesia technique commonly used for pain management during surgical procedures. Diaphragmatic hernia is not directly contraindication for epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes a mastectomy for breast cancer. Post-operatively, the surgeon decides to use a closed suction drain. Which of the following drain types is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Jackson Pratt (JP) drain, which is a type of closed suction drain commonly used in various surgical procedures, including mastectomies.

 

Jackson Pratt drain:

  • Consists of a soft, flattened silicone tube connected to a soft plastic bulb
  • The bulb can be compressed to create negative pressure
  • Typically clear or translucent, allowing easy visualization of drainage
  • Suitable for various surgeries, including breast, plastic, and abdominal procedures
  • Easy to empty and maintain by patients

Penrose drain (Option A)

This is an open, passive drain consisting of a soft rubber tube. It relies on gravity and capillary action for drainage.

Jackson-pratt drain (Option B)

Consists of a soft, flattened silicone tube connected to a soft plastic bulb

The bulb can be compressed to create negative pressure

Suitable for various surgeries, including breast, plastic, and abdominal procedures

Romovac suction drain (Option C)

Another type of closed suction drain

Uses a spring-loaded mechanism to create constant negative pressure

Often used in orthopedic surgeries and joint replacements

Hemovac drain (Option D)

This is another brand of closed suction drain, similar in principle to the JP drain. However, Hemovac drains typically have a larger, more rigid collection chamber compared to the soft, compressible bulb of the JP

questions.text: What is triage for?

choices.text: To assess the impact of a disaster
To classify the priority of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct answer C) To classify the priority of treatment

Explanation:

  • Triage is the process of classifying patients based on the severity of their condition and the priority of treatment required.
  • It is commonly used in emergencies or mass casualty incidents with limited resources.
  • Triage helps in efficiently allocating resources by prioritising patients based on the urgency of their condition.

 

To prepare for a disaster (Option A) is incorrect because the purpose of triage is not to prepare for a disaster but rather to assess and prioritise patients during a disaster or emergency situation.

To assess the impact of a disaster (Option B) is incorrect because while triage is a part of disaster response, its main objective is not to assess the overall impact of a disaster but to categorise patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses.

To rehabilitate following a disaster (Option D) triage is not involved in the rehabilitation process after a disaster. Triage focuses on initial assessment and prioritisation of patients during the acute phase of a disaster.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument depicted below, which is utilized for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Veress needle

Explanation:

  • The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create a pneumoperitoneum, which is the insufflation of carbon dioxide gas into the peritoneal cavity to create a working space during laparoscopic procedures.
  • The Veress needle is inserted through a small incision or through the umbilicus, and its tip is equipped with a spring-loaded mechanism that allows for controlled penetration of the abdominal wall. Once inserted, carbon dioxide gas is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.

 

Morris' needle (Option B) Not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum; it is mainly used in general surgical procedures for drainage or infiltration.

Yankauer suction tip (Option C) A rigid suction device used primarily in oropharyngeal and surgical suctioning, not for insufflation.

Von Graefe needle (Option D) A specialized needle used in ophthalmic surgery, particularly for cataract procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery

questions.text: What is the needle placement angle when using the interrupted suturing technique to suture a laceration in the ER?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) 90 degrees

Explanation:

  • When using the interrupted suturing technique, the needle should be placed perpendicular to the skin surface, creating a 90-degree angle.
  • This angle allows for proper penetration and closure of the wound edges.
  • By inserting the needle at a right angle to the skin, the sutures can adequately hold the tissues together and provide optimal wound closure and healing.

 

60 degrees (Option A) would be too shallow for proper needle placement during interrupted suturing.

70 degrees (Option B) is also too shallow for interrupted suturing.

80 degrees (Option C) is closer to the correct angle of 90 degrees but is still not ideal for interrupted suturing.

questions.text: What might you suspect as the diagnosis for a 26-year-old male patient who arrives at the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain and constipation persisting for the last three days? The patient recalls being struck in the abdomen by a bull three days ago. Could you examine the provided X-ray to aid in your assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

  • Hollow viscus perforation refers to the rupture or perforation of a hollow organ within the abdominal cavity.
  • In this case, the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, along with a history of abdominal trauma from a bull gore, raise suspicion for a hollow viscus injury.
  • The X-ray suggestive of perforation, such as free air under the diaphragm

 

Hemothorax (Option A) Accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity due to trauma, does not match the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation resulting from a bull gore injury.

Pneumothorax (Option C) Air in the pleural cavity causing lung collapse, doesn't align with the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation due to bull gore injury. Pneumothorax typically presents with sudden chest pain, breathing difficulty, and decreased breath sounds.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) Blockage of intestinal flow, partially fits the patient's presentation but doesn't explain the bull gore injury and X-ray findings of perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is accurate for measuring the nasogastric tube?

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum
Angle of mouth to tragus to xiphisternum
Ala of nose to angle of mandible to xiphisternum
Angle of mouth to ear lobule to umbilicus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tip of nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum

Explanation:

  • The correct method for measuring a nasogastric tube involves measuring the distance from the tip of the patient's nose to the ear lobule and then down to the xiphisternum, which is the lower end of the sternum. This measurement helps determine the appropriate length of the nasogastric tube that needs to be inserted.

Nasogastric (NG) Tubes:

  • Inserted through the nose and passed into the stomach
  • Larger in diameter (typically 14-18 French)
  • Common markings:
    • Measurement markings in centimeters to indicate the insertion depth
    • 'STOMACH' printed on the tube to confirm correct placement

Indications:

  • Decompression of the stomach (e.g., in intestinal obstruction)
  • Enteral feeding in adults and older children
  • Medication administration

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 25-year-old patient who has been experiencing abdominal pain and fever for the past three days, based on the provided chest X-ray taken in an upright position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

The case of abdominal pain, fever, and an upright X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm is most likely diagnosed as hollow viscus perforation.

  • The contents of the organ, including digestive juices and bacteria, can leak into the surrounding tissues or abdominal cavity, leading to a serious condition known as peritonitis.
  • Diagnosis: Free air under the diaphragm (upright plain film taken at the level of the diaphragm). (Option A)

 

Pneumoperitoneum

  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free gas in the peritoneal cavity, typically indicating a perforated viscus (e.g., perforated peptic ulcer).
  • Causes:
    • Common: Perforated peptic ulcers, bowel obstruction, inflammatory conditions, ischemia, injury during colonoscopy.
    • Other causes without peritonitis: Postoperative (up to 7 days), peritoneal dialysis, sealed perforation, and tracking from pneumomediastinum.
  • Diagnosis on Imaging:
    • Erect CXR: Free gas is seen under the right hemidiaphragm (cupola sign), but it is difficult to differentiate on the left due to gastric or colonic gas.
    • Supine AXR: Right upper quadrant gas in the perihepatic, subhepatic space, Morrison’s pouch, and ligament visualisation (e.g., falciform ligament).
    • Rigler’s Sign: Visualization of both sides of the bowel wall due to surrounding gas.
    • CT Scan: Most sensitive; small volumes of gas seen in the liver or peritoneal recesses, often using broad window settings.

 

Gastric volvulus (Option: B) occurs when the stomach twists around its axis, leading to obstruction and preventing the passage of food and fluids. It typically causes symptoms like vomiting, nausea, and distension, but not free air under the diaphragm, as seen in hollow viscus perforation. Imaging, such as X-rays or CT scans, may reveal an abnormal stomach position, often showing twisted loops.

 

Liver abscess (Option C) appears as a well-defined dark area on ultrasound and a hypodense lesion with a defined rim on CT. It may cause fever and abdominal pain but doesn’t cause free air under the diaphragm. Diagnosis is typically made with ultrasound or CT, which shows localised fluid collections.

 

Empyema thoracis (Option D) is an infection in the pleural space, causing fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. It doesn’t cause free air under the diaphragm. On X-ray, it shows a loculated pleural effusion, with possible diaphragm elevation. CT reveals thickened pleura and fluid collections, while ultrasound aids in detecting and draining fluid.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side. Vitals were unstable. What will be your immediate management?

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space
Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical findings and X-ray confirm a right-sided Tension Pneumothorax and immediate management involves decompressing the pleural space by inserting a wide-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space.
  • It is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural cavity under pressure, causing lung collapse on the affected side, mediastinal shift, and severe impairment of cardiovascular function.

Pathology:

  • It occurs when air enters the pleural cavity through a "one-way valve" mechanism, leading to lung collapse and mediastinal shift towards the opposite side.
  • ↑Pleural pressure→ Opposite lung compression→ ↓venous return→ ↓cardiac output and potentially sudden death.

Aetiology:

  • Penetrating chest trauma.
  • Blunt chest trauma with parenchymal lung injury.
  • Iatrogenic lung injury (e.g., central venous catheterisation), and mechanical positive-pressure ventilation.

Clinical Features:

  • Restlessness, tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and chest pain.
  • Distended neck veins, hyper-resonance, and decreased or absent breath sound on the affected side.
  • Late findings may include tracheal deviation and cyanosis.
  • Hypotension and severe mediastinal/tracheal shift are also common.

Management:

  • Immediate decompression with a large-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line or the "safe triangle" via needle thoracostomy or finger thoracostomy. (Option A)
  • Followed by intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.
  • Provide oxygen, analgesics, antibiotics, and ventilator support if necessary.

 

Wide bore needle decompression and IV fluids (Option B): While needle decompression is the correct initial management for tension pneumothorax, IV fluids are secondary and do not directly address the life-threatening issue of air accumulation in the pleural space. The priority is to relieve the pressure with a needle insertion, followed by stabilization with fluids.

Intubation and positive pressure ventilation (Option C) are important for managing respiratory failure or compromised airways, but in the case of a tension pneumothorax, these could worsen the condition by increasing the pressure in the chest. The first step should always be to decompress the pleural space to relieve pressure.

e-FAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) (Option D) exam is useful for detecting pneumothorax, hemothorax, or internal bleeding, but in this case, the patient’s clinical signs strongly suggest a tension pneumothorax. Immediate decompression is needed before further diagnostic imaging.

questions.text: A patient, after a road traffic accident, presented with pain in the abdomen. The resident examined the child and found that vitals were stable, and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contrast-enhanced CT scan

Explanation:

A CT scan is a non-invasive tool that provides detailed images of abdominal organs and can identify injuries, bleeding, or fractures in patients with abdominal pain after a road traffic accident.

  • The most commonly injured organ in:
    • Blunt trauma abdomen is the spleen > liver.
    • Penetrating trauma is the liver.
    • Gunshot injury is the small intestine > large bowel > liver > intra-abdominal vasculature.
  • The most commonly injured part of the bowel in blunt trauma abdomen is the jejunum and the ileum.
  • The most commonly injured structure in seat belt injury is the mesentery.
  • First investigation done in blunt trauma abdomen: FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma).
  • Investigation of choice for stable blunt trauma abdomen: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT scan). (Option A)

 

Retrograde urethrogram (Option B) is used to assess urethral injuries, especially with pelvic fractures or blood at the meatus, but it isn't the best initial test for abdominal pain with left lumbar tenderness.

Wait and watch (Option C) may be considered if the patient is stable with no immediate concern, but in trauma with abdominal pain and tenderness, proper investigation is crucial to rule out serious injuries.

Emergency laparotomy (Option D) is a major surgery and should be done only if there's clear evidence of a life-threatening condition, like active bleeding or peritonitis. It's not the first choice for investigation here.

questions.text: The position of the patient in the image shown below is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reverse Trendelenburg position

Explanation:

  • The position of the patient shown in the image is known as the Reverse Trendelenburg position.
  • The patient is placed with the head elevated above the level of the head and the feet lowered than the head.
  • This position is often used during upper abdominal surgeries.

Positioning on the Operating Table

Position

Description

Uses and Complications

Supine Position

Most common position for general surgical procedures.

Modifications of Supine position:

  • Rose’s position
  • Shoulder and Arm Extended
  • Trendelenburg Position
  • Reverse Trendelenburg Position
  • Fowler's Position

General surgeries.

 

Rose's Position

Supine with slight neck extension.

Head and neck surgery.

Shoulder and Arm Extended

Supine with shoulder and arm extended.

Axillary and breast surgery.

Trendelenburg Position

(Option C)

Head end tilted down, knees slightly flexed.

Pelvic procedures, resuscitating patients in shock.

Reverse Trendelenburg Position

The head end tilted upward, placing the head higher than the feet.

Upper abdominal surgeries.

Complication: Right shoulder pain due to CO2 collected under the right dome of the diaphragm during laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

Fowler's Position

Semi-sitting with the trunk raised at 40° and knees bent.

Neurosurgery, shoulder surgeries, patients with heart or respiratory failure.

Complication: Increased risk of air embolism.

Prone Position

The patient is intubated and log-rolled onto the operating bed with help.

Spinal surgery, extra levator abdominoperineal excision for rectal cancer.

Jackknife Position

(Option B)

(Prone Position Modification)

Chest supported, abdomen relaxed by flexing at the hips.

Provides excellent access to the perineum.

Complication: Positional asphyxia

Lateral Decubitus or Kidney Position

Lower leg flexed, pillow between legs, upper leg flexed in an exaggerated position.

Draining abscesses, lateral thoracotomy, urological and retroperitoneal procedures.

Complication: Increased risk of brachial plexus injury due to hyperextension

Lithotomy Position

Supine with hips and knees flexed, legs in stirrups, hips flexed to 90°.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

Complication: Common peroneal nerve injury if legs are not supported properly

Lloyd-Davies Position

(Option A)

(Lithotomy Modification)

Supine with hips minimally flexed (~15°) and a 30° head-down tilt.

Gynecological, perineal, and urological procedures.

questions.text: FAST stands for

choices.text: First assessment with sonography in trauma
Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma

Explanation:

  • Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma is the correct full form of FAST.
  • It is a rapid, non-invasive ultrasound examination used primarily in trauma settings to detect free fluid (such as blood) in the abdomen or Thorax.
  • It can be used to assess the hepatorenal, splenorenal, and pelvis spaces for fluid that is considered to be blood in a trauma case.
  • It is a valuable tool in the early management of trauma patients as it helps identify life-threatening conditions, such as internal bleeding, which may require immediate surgical intervention.

Other options A, C & D are not correct.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has been declared brain dead, and her family has chosen to donate her organs. Who would be the most suitable recipient of her organs?

choices.text: 50-year alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1 month abstinence

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 32 year old woman with renal failure

Explanation:

  • A 32-year-old woman with renal failure is the most suitable recipient for the donor's organs as the age match between the donor and the recipient increases the likelihood of a successful transplant.
  • When it comes to organ donation, the primary considerations for choosing the recipient include matching the donor's organ characteristics such as size, blood type, and tissue compatibility, as well as the recipient's health status and likelihood of receiving benefit from the transplant.
  • Optimal transplantation involves choosing donors and recipients of similar age, among other factors, to minimise compatibility challenges

14-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (Option A): A 14-year-old child with multi-organ dysfunction syndrome is likely to have a more complicated prognosis, and the organs of a 32-year-old woman may not be the best match for a pediatric recipient.

50-year alcoholic man with liver cirrhosis with 1-month abstinence (Option B): Even though he has been abstinent for a month, liver transplant eligibility often requires a longer period of sobriety, as relapse can occur and impact the success of the transplant. Additionally, liver transplants are often prioritized for individuals with urgent needs or a better prognosis.

70-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease (Option C): The 70-year-old woman's potential benefit from a kidney transplant needs careful consideration of her age and associated comorbidities.

Match the following

1. Urine Bag

questions.text:
The components of qSOFA scoring include:

A. Mental status

B. Blood pressure

C. Respiratory rate

D. Heart rate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A, B & C

Explanation:

  • qSOFA is quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment scoring, and it uses 3 components, i.e.;
    • Respiratory rate (≥ 22 breaths per minute)
    • Altered mental status (GCS ≤ 15)
    • Low systolic blood pressure (≤ 100)
  • qSOFA is a bedside score that helps identify patients at risk of death from a suspected infection.
  • Heart rate is not included in the qSOFA score. (Statement D ruled out)

A. Breast surgery

  • Breast surgery can also lead to Thoracodorsal nerve injury.

B. Thyroid surgery

questions.text: Which one of the following is excluded from the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Taking CT scan of the patient

  • Taking a CT scan is not part of the primary survey because it is a diagnostic tool used in the secondary survey.

ATLS protocol/ Advanced Trauma Life Support protocol:

  • Primary survey:
    • It includes the airway, breathing, circulation, disability or neurologic condition, and exposure and environmental control, which is known by the mnemonic ABCDE.
    • The airway is assessed immediately by a verbal response, and if it is not clear, needful intervention is carried out. (Option D ruled out)
    • Breathing is evaluated by chest movements, breath sounds and saturation and assisted ventilation is provided if needed.
    • Circulation assessment includes ruling out shock. Assessment of circulatory status (e.g., blood pressure, pulses, bleeding), maintaining IV access and immediate fluid resuscitation are recommended according to the ATLS in case of shock. (Option A ruled out)
    • Neurological assessment is done to assess any traumatic brain or spinal injury and neurogenic shock. The GCS score is evaluated.
    • Environmental control: The patient's clothes should be removed for a thorough examination, and hypothermia should be prevented (warm IV fluids, raised room temperature, body warmers). (Option B ruled out)
  • Secondary survey:
    • This includes a complete patient history and a thorough head-to-toe assessment. It is done almost immediately in stable patients and includes radiological investigations.
    • The AMPLE history mnemonic is used to gather key details (Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last meal, Events/Environment related to the injury).
    • Face deformities, posterior neck injuries, the torso, a per rectal examination for GI bleed, and prostate location are all included in this step.
    • A thorough neurological examination and evaluation of superficial injuries are done.
    • The complete physical examination and use of imaging are now included in the tertiary survey.
